summary: This document is an email forwarded to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) from an anonymous individual claiming to be a previously unknown victim of Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein. The writer, a lifelong model, offers information about Maxwell and identifies Jean Luc Brunel as a central figure in international sex trafficking, claiming he is far worse than Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Identified by the email writer as a perpetrator and co-conspirator with Jeffrey Epstein, though described as 'nothing compared' to Jean Luc Brunel.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned by the email writer as a perpetrator alongside Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Identified by the email writer as Epstein's partner, the writer's former agent, and the primary alleged trafficker described as '100x worse than Maxwell' and responsible for international sex trafficking for 40 years.

connections.description: The email writer identifies both as perpetrators they were a victim of, implying their association in criminal activity.
The email writer explicitly states 'Epstein's partner Jean Luc Brunel', indicating a business or criminal partnership.
Both are mentioned by the writer as part of the same network of perpetrators, with Brunel described as far more significant.
The writer states Brunel was their modeling agent, indicating a professional relationship.

events.title: Victim Outreach to Prosecutors
events.description: An anonymous individual sends an email to the U.S. Attorney's Office claiming to be a previously unknown victim of Maxwell and Epstein, offering new information.

keyFacts: An anonymous lifelong model and former teen runaway contacted prosecutors in November 2021, identifying as a previously unknown victim of Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.
The writer claims Jean Luc Brunel, a modeling agent and Epstein's partner, is '100x worse than Maxwell' and has been trafficking women internationally for 40 years.
The writer offers to provide additional information and stories about Maxwell and the network, indicating potential new evidence for investigators.
The correspondence highlights the ongoing impact of the cases on victims and suggests the criminal network involved 'MANY others they all knew.'
